Row.Text: Conquest of the New World
Sail west looking for a passage to the Orient and see what you find. Or play as a Native American civilization facing an unexpected threat from the sea.

SCENARIO DESCRIPTION[NEWLINE]The year is 1492. To the courts of England, France, and Spain come intrepid explorers, anxious to voyage across the Atlantic in search of a western route to China and the Indies. Will they find a new trade route and uncover untold riches from the Asian shores? Or will they perhaps run aground on undiscovered lands along their way? Will native peoples be receptive to the knowledge and trade prospects presented to them, or will they fight against the invaders of their homeland? What riches, fame, and opportunities await those who brave the unknown waters? What path will you choose? Who will prevail in the struggle for supremacy over this New World?[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]VICTORY CONDITIONS[NEWLINE]Victory goes to the first civilization to reach a score of 1000 VP. You earn bonus VP for reaching China with an exploring Caravel and for returning Treasure units to your capital. Play as many times as you like trying each of the six civs: the map of America changes each time you start a new game.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]SPECIAL RULES[NEWLINE]Units at sea are afflicted with Scurvy, a "promotion" that may cause them to lose health each turn they end outside friendly lands. Build the Navigation School national wonder to combat this malady. European powers may not declare war on one another until one of them researches the Piracy technology. Treasure units are created when cities are razed or from the El Dorado and Potosi natural wonders (if they exist on this map). Move these civilian units to your capital to earn gold and VP.

In its most basic form, Imperialism describes an unequal relationship between one nation and another, where the former has some amount of control over the latter country - usually in the form of some kind of empire. Imperialistic dynasties can be found in all the histories of the world, from China to Rome to Britain, and imperialism as a concept has existed for thousands of years, just about as long as governments in general. The term "imperialism", however, wasn't coined until the 16th century, where it was used to describe the foreign policies and proceedings of nations like Spain, Britain, Belgium, and the Netherlands, as they swiftly built up imperial ties with the Americas.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While Imperialism is traditionally connected with the large, iconic, militaristic empire, it can be exhibited in a much more subtle manner. Formal control of the weaker state's government isn't always necessary, and a stronger civilization will sometimes control a weaker one purely through indirect economic, political or religious means.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Imperialism is a paper tiger."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Mao Zedong[NEWLINE][TAB]

Naval Tradition describes both a civilization's dedication to sea travel and a standing navy, as well as the individual traditions and customs employed by those navies. Many island and ocean-side civilizations like Britain and Spain have long standing naval traditions, as the ocean played a major part of their economic and political development. While some landlocked countries employed professional soldiers to keep the peace and wage wars, naval-minded civs kept flotillas and fleets of ships rather than land-bound armies, plying the waves for enemy vessels and pirates.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Many traditions born aboard the earliest navies are still followed by sailors today, and others have expanded beyond the confines of the ship to people on land. Some practices, like wearing bellbottom pants, using decorative sleeve buttons on jackets, or "minding your P's and Q's" all have their roots in naval traditions.
Rise of the NEWORLDs
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Don't talk to me about naval tradition. It's nothing but rum, sodomy and the lash."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Winston Churchill[NEWLINE][TAB]

Professional soldiers are a marked improvement over the rag tag, cobbled-together militias exhibited by most early civilizations. These fulltime soldiers are better-equipped, better trained, and are all-in-all more effective than your average farmer with a leather jerkin and a pitchfork. The Roman Empire created one of the world's first standing armies staffed with professional soldiers, who were a key part to their sweeping military victories. In Europe, some of the first professional soldiers were employed by Charles VII of France in 1445, and later by King James II of Britain in 1685.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Professional soldiers are a staple part of a modern civilization's army and defense system, and can be found employed in many of the world's developed countries.

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Although a soldier by profession, I have never felt any sort of fondness for war, and I have never advocated it, except as a means of peace."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Ulysses S. Grant[NEWLINE][TAB]

Raiding, pillaging, unspeakable violence at sea - a pirate's life is a good one. Often romanticized by popular film and media, pirates are anything but the witty, wisecracking Captain Jack Sparrows and Pirate Kings entertaining the young masses. These naval criminals took cargo by force from other ships, raided seaside towns, and were a general menace to all forms of civilized society. Piracy has probably been around for as long as civilizations have ported goods and peoples across the seas - one of the earliest records of piracy dates back to the 13th century BC.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some of the most famous piracy accounts are attributed to the European Vikings, who terrorized coastal villages and holdings, and the Caribbean pirates, who generally liked to seize Spanish treasure ships fat and heavy with gold. This “classic” era of piracy is the one most commonly depicted in films and books, and lasted from about 1560 to 1720. While this illustrious pirate with saber sword and jaunty hat is relegated now to the work of fiction, piracy is still found rampant in many waters, especially off the coast of the Arabian Peninsula. Piracy however should not be confused or interchanged with the act of privateering, a form of naval raiding authorized by a legal government, usually for wartime benefit.
Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Privateer[ENDCOLOR] and allows European powers to declare war on each other.

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The only rules that really matter are these: what a man can do and what a man can't do... I can let you drown, but I can't bring this ship into Tortuga all by me onesies, savvy? So, can you sail under the command of a pirate, or can you not?"[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Captain Jack Sparrow[NEWLINE][TAB]

While many ships are engineered to cross oceans quickly or take the greatest amount of cargo in the smallest possible space, warships were designed for one purpose alone - destroying other ships. Besides obviously being armed with some form of weapon (traditionally things like cannon or rams), warships can also withstand more damage and are much more maneuverable than something like a merchant or passenger vessel.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]As naval technologies have advanced, so has the warship. Galleys and triremes were early forms of warships capable of ramming enemy vessels, but usually combat was performed by the army onboard. However, once cannon became capable of quick reloads, large sail-driven ships were employed which held rows of cannon along each side of the craft. Eventually these wooden ships were given up for ones made of iron and steel, and sails were abandoned for steam and nuclear power. While modern warships bear little resemblance to the earliest galleys, they still keep to the same basic design principles - be capable of destroying the other guy first, before he can take out you.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Damn the torpedoes, Full speed ahead!"[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Admiral David Glasgow Farragut[NEWLINE][TAB]

Usually formed by an elite group of armed retainers, royal guards are the traditional military or ceremonial unit employed to protect royalty or important clergy. Historically, these elite members have also served a dual political purpose, as their unique position would allow them to sway a given monarch's opinion or play a key part in any sort of coup or uprising.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some regiments of royal guards have become celebrated and well-known outside of their given countries, such as Spain's Tropas de la Casa Real and the French Musketeers. France's Musketeers were technically only a junior unit of the French Royal Guard, beneath the Garde de Corpe who actually performed most of the bodyguard responsibilities. But thanks in part to Alexandre Dumas' work, The Three Musketeers, they have become some of the most popular and recognizable royal guards of any civilization.
Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Musketeer[ENDCOLOR], an enhanced version of the standard Musketman.

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"This world is an uncertain realm, filled with danger. Honor underminded by the pursuit of power, freedom sacrificed when the weak are oppressed by the strong. But there are those who oppose these powerful forces, who dedicate their lives to truth, honor, and freedom. These men are known as Musketeers. Rise"[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - King Louis[NEWLINE][TAB]

In many world religions, there exist special communities and organizations of devout individuals who live apart from the majority of society, usually to keep more perfectly in line with their specific religious beliefs. These religious orders often take the physical form of monasteries, a building or complex where the pious can work and live.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]While some religious orders were content to reside and pray in their native countries, some instead were founded for the sole purpose of expansion and spreading their beliefs to new peoples. The Jesuit missionaries in the Americas were one such religious order. These Jesuits traveled across the Atlantic and set up monasteries and missions on the American soil, where they taught the local people the tenets of their faith and the basics of western education.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The Jesuits I know who have died and all their lives were great teachers, they're the least remembered people."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Daniel Berrigan[NEWLINE][TAB]

Once the Spanish arrived in the Americas and began shipping their new finds and treasures back to Europe, they needed to develop a new, more efficient method of sailing in order to combat the increased pressure of pirate raids on their ships. The Spanish Treasure Fleet was the answer - a special convoy system of ships which was strictly regulated in both docking and sailing practices. Ships departing from the Americas along the Spanish Main were instructed to sail en masse along a specific sea lane, allowing them to be more easily protected by a smaller armed force. These ships then only sailed to restricted, protected, port towns (like Seville), again lessening the risk of pirate raid.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Treasure Fleet was employed by Spain from the 16th to 18th century with much success, and is still counted as one of the most profitable and effective naval operations in history. However, the loss of some important coastal cities along the Spanish Main in the 1700s began to threaten the continued existence of the fleet. In a bid to combat this, King Charles III loosened the rigorous system in 1765, and gave more colonies access to the fleet in the 1780s. However, the last full fleet sailed in 1790 and shipping between the two continents was relegated to smaller groups of ships on an as-needed basis.
Grants the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Defensive Embarkation[ENDCOLOR] promotion to all land units, allowing them to defend against naval attacks.

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Gold is a treasure, and he who possesses it does all he wishes to in this world, and succeeds in helping souls into paradise."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Christpher Columbus[NEWLINE][TAB]

The Treasure Unit encompasses the entirety of the Spanish Treasure Fleet system in the New World, from mine to destination. After gold or silver was excavated in various locations in the Americas, it was shipped along land by llama and mule, traveling well-documented routes to specific port towns along the Spanish Main. From these ports, the treasure was then loaded onto galleons and merchant vessels, which traveled together in a massive convoy across the Atlantic Ocean. These ships followed a precise path each time they crossed the Atlantic to Spain, allowing themselves to be easily protected from pirates and thieves. These treasure units helped make Spain the wealthiest civilization at the time, and were instrumental in the creation of one of the world’s most impressive naval operations.

A civilian unit unique to this scenario that represents a land mule train (or when embarked a treasure fleet) containing gold or silver from the New World. Return it to your capital to earn gold and victory points.

This Unit is stronger in combat than the Musketman and fights at double-strength against mounted units.
Renaissance Era unit that specializes in scouting and colonizing overseas. May be built by any civ.

The Conquistador is a multi-purpose unit that is strong both on land and at sea. It is an exceptional scout on land with extra visibility and the ability to found new cities. In the water, the Conquistador has the defensive embarkation promotion that allows it to defend itself against naval units. It also suffers no penalty when attacking cities, unlike the Knight.
Only the Maya may build this unit. It is cheaper and available sooner than the Archer, which it replaces.

The Atlatlist is the Mayan unique unit, replacing the Archer. Atlatlists are both cheaper than a traditional Archer, and available earlier without having to research Archery. This early game advantage allows other research priorities to come into play.

The Atlatlists were super-specialized dart-throwers, employing a long, wooden, spear-like object to hurl their darts towards the intended target at a great speed. This implement, called an atlatl, had a small cup on one end on which the dart would rest, and a channel cut down the length for it to travel down. Using an atlatl, the Atlatlist could launch a dart over 300 feet and up to 60 miles an hour - a good deal farther and faster than a simple hand-thrown projectile. The Mayan Atlatlists would have been capable of devastating enemy lines from afar, provided they had a clear line of sight to the target.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some of the earliest atlatls date back to roughly 400,000 years ago, used by the extinct Homo heidelbergensis. Homo sapiens are thought to have used an early version of the atlatl starting in the Upper Paleolithic Era, about 15,500 BC.
This Unit has a higher [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength than the Musketman, making it the most powerful melee unit in the game. May be built by any civ.
The Musketeer is significantly more powerful than the Musketman, making it the most powerful foot soldier unit in the game

História

Francis I was King of France from 1515 until 1547, during which time he helped form the Franco-Ottoman alliance with Suleiman I. The Holy Roman Emperor Charles V was Francis’s greatest nemesis and would be the target of several military campaigns. At the Battle of Pavia in 1525, Francis would be captured by Charles and held captive for over a year until turning over his two sons, Henry and Francis, in exchange for his freedom.

The Inuits are indigenous people inhabiting the Arctic regions of Greenland and North America.
The Seminoles are some of the indigenous people of Florida, and are closely related to the Muscogee (both are Creek peoples).
The Lakotas are a group of indigenous inhabitants of the North American plains.
The Caribs are some of the indigenous people of the West Indies. They fought some of the earliest wars against the Spanish.

The Cherokee are a group of indigenous inhabitants of the southeastern Unites States. They are closely related to the Iroquois, so it is thought they migrated south from the Great Lakes in prehistoric times.
The Algonquin are a group of indigenous inhabitants of Quebec. They became archrivals of the Iroquois with whom they competed in the fur trade.
The Hurons are some of the indigenous people of Canada, primarily living on the north shore of Lake Ontario at the time of European contact.
The Muscogee are some of the indigenous people of the southeastern United States and descended from the Mississippian culture.
The Wabanaki are the "people of the dawn" -- indigenous people of the maritime provinces of eastern Canada.
The Mapuche are some of the indigenous people of Chile and Argentina. They were referred to as Araucanians by the Spanish colonists.
The Arawaks are a group of indigenous inhabitants of the West Indies. They were the first natives encountered by Christopher Columbus.
The Maya are indigenous inhabitants of the Yucatan peninsula. They were a civilization skilled in mathematics and astronomy and builders of elaborate carved stone pyramids.
The Yanomami are an indigenous tribe of the Amazon basin. They are a stone age culture that had no known contact with Europeans until 1929.
The Muisca are a group of indigenous inhabitants of the central highlands of Colombia. They first had contact with the Spanish in 1537 and are a likely source of the legend of El Dorado.
The Hopi are some of the indigenous people of the southwestern United States. They were the first encountered by Coronado's expedition in 1540.
The Anasazi are an ancient indigenous culture, forerunners of the modern Puebloan peoples. The Anasazi are known for having build the Mesa Verde cliff dwellings.

Will native peoples be receptive to the knowledge and trade prospects presented to them, or will they fight against the invaders of their homeland? What riches, fame, and opportunities await those who brave the unknown waters? What path will you choose? Who will prevail in the struggle for supremacy over this New World?[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]VICTORY CONDITIONS[NEWLINE]Victory goes to the highest score after 150 turns. You earn bonus VP for reaching China with an exploring Great Admiral. Americans earn victory points for [ICON_PEACE] Faith and Europeans for [ICON_GOLD] Gold. Play as many times as you like trying each of the ten civs: the map of America changes each time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]SPECIAL RULES[NEWLINE]European powers may not declare war on one another until one of them researches Piracy. Treasure units are created when cities are razed or from the El Dorado and Potosi natural wonders. Units at sea are afflicted with Scurvy, a "promotion" build the Navigation School national wonder to combat this malady. European civs want to spread their religion to the New World. See the BRIEFING screen for full details on special rules.

História

An infanta of Castile, Catherine was the daughter of Joanna of Castile and Philip of Habsburg. At the age of 18 she was married to her first cousin John III of Portugal in 1525 AD, eventually bearing him nine children, two of which survived to majority. With John's death in 1557, she became regent for the heir, her grandson Sebastian. In 1562 she surrendered the regency to her brother-in-law Cardinal Henry, John's younger brother. As queen and later regent, Catherine had advocated Portugal's expansion in Brazil, as well as colonial ventures in Africa. She died at the age of 71 in February 1578, just months before King Sebastian's own demise in Morocco.

The sack of captured cities in the New World was conducted as a matter of policy by European invaders to break native morale, or occasionally simply for loot. An example of the former would be Gonzalo Pizzaro's sack of the new Incan capital of Vilcabamba in 1539 AD; of the latter, buccaneer Henry Morgan's sack of Panama City in 1671.

The period of exploration of the New World was followed by a period of conquest and state-sponsored colonization as the European powers sought to increase their power and wealth. Within 200 years of Columbus' voyage, Spain, Portugal, France, England, even the Netherlands and Sweden had joined the race to claim the vast territories of the Americas.
Convoy System
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Convoy System[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+6 [ICON_GOLD] Gold from all your sea trade routes.

Although convoys had been used since the 9th Century AD during times of war to protect troop transports and invasions, the increasing audacity of pirates and privateers in the Caribbean led the Spanish merchants and eventually the crown to institute a convoy system to guard the wealth being brought back to Europe from the New World. Some of the Spanish and Portuguese convoys might contain several hundred merchants, such as the Spanish bullion convoys that sailed from the 1520s until 1790.

Until Columbus imported horses to the West Indies on his second voyage in 1493 AD, there were no equines surviving in the Americas. Descended from stock abandoned by conquistadors, various breeds spread quickly across the North American plains, where the heretofore primitive nomads quickly made the horse the mainstay of their society and culture.

The motivation for overseas holdings was the result of a range of factors – limited economic growth, religious fervor, overpopulation, cultural stagnation, unbreakable military balance, among others – that spurred the European powers to seek to establish colonial empires. Already spanning the globe, from the Orient to Africa, the European monarchs saw the Americas as offering seemingly limitless opportunities to expand those empires.

A port of call is an intermediary stop on a ship's trade route where it can take on provisions and water and transfer cargo and passengers. Colonial ports such as San Juan and Santo Domingo in the Caribbean, St. Augustine and Philadelphia in North America, and Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires were instrumental in securing the New World for the Europeans.

A style of fortification, built of unmortised stone usually on steep hillsides, common to the native cultures of the central Andes: the Wari, the Tiwanaku, and later the Inca. The Inca often used these fortifications as administrative centers as well, such as Puka Pukara, the "red fortress" which guarded one of the approaches to Cuzco.

As pirâmides escalonadas mesoamericanas - mais semelhantes aos zigurates da Mesopotâmia do que às pirâmides de lados lisos - eram a forma arquitetônica dominante para a maioria das estruturas religiosas nas olmecas, astecas, maias, zapotecas, tarascos e outras sociedades. Frequentemente com elaboradas esculturas simbólicas, relevos, murais e mosaicos, os maiores (como a Grande Pirâmide de Cholula) eram símbolos duradouros do poder desses estados teocráticos.

[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Ransom[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Gain [ICON_GOLD] Gold for each enemy killed.

Following a continental tradition dating back to ancient times, the European adventurers took the leaders of native tribes prisoner and held them for ransom, often in the name of their own king. In 1532 AD, for instance, Francisco Pizzaro was awarded a ransom the modern equivalent of $2 billion by the Inca to have their prince Atahualpa freed (although Pizzaro reneged and had the prince executed).
Sacred Land
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Sacred Land[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]If you founded a minor religion, gain a bonus Reformation belief.

Many native North American religions are animistic, in that spiritual essences are embodied by natural physical objects - animals, plants, weather phenomena, and even certain places. For many tribes, from the Haudenausaunee (Iroquois) to the Lakota Sioux, protecting their sacred lands - such as the Cohoes Falls or Black Hills or Mount Shasta - was a matter of faith as well as tribal policy.
Temple of the Gods
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Temple of the Gods[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]Build Temples in half the usual time. Temples increase a city's [ICON_GOLD] Gold output by 25%.

Many of the early Mesoamerican kingdoms were animistic theocracies, and the "national" temple was as important as the palace in the capital. The oldest of these "temples of the gods" date to the PreClassic Era (roughly 1800 BC to 200 AD), many of these taking the form of pyramids dedicated to jaguar or serpent deities.
Unified Nation
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Unified Nation[ENDCOLOR][NEWLINE]+1 Local [ICON_HAPPINESS_1] Happiness and +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith from every National Wonder.

As among other native peoples, in several places disparate tribes with a common cultural and/or linguistic heritage banded together into a single "nation," such as the Oneida, Cherokee and Navaho. Often the impetus for the unification of long-time enemies was the arrival of Europeans, for some native leaders recognized the threat these newcomers posed to the tribes.
